net.joeclark.proceduralgeneration

Interface MarkovChain<T extends Serializable>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of a "state"
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    MultiOrderMarkovChain

    public interface MarkovChain<T extends Serializable>
    A Markov chain maps current states to possible future states, usually defined with probabilities. This is useful in procedural generation, for example to model which letters in a language most frequently follow a given letter, or to model which weather conditions most likely follow a given weather state. For each known state, a MarkovChain knows or can calculate the possible following states, so a client should be able to traverse the "chain" as many iterations as he likes (e.g. for a simulation). In most cases these transitions will be weighted by a probability distribution or observed frequencies, so not all transitions from any given state will be equally likely.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Set<T> allKnownStates()
      The set of all "states" that the model is aware of.
      Set<T> allPossibleNext(List<T> currentSequence)
      Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method provides the set of all the states that may occur next in the chain.
      boolean hasModel()
      Tests whether the model has been initialized, populated, or trained with data.
      T unweightedRandomNext(List<T> currentSequence)
      Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method chooses one state at random from the set of states that may occur next in the chain, without considering relative weights or probabilities.
      T weightedRandomNext(List<T> currentSequence)
      Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method chooses one state at random from the set of states that may occur next in the chain, based on a set of weights or an absolute or relative probability distribution of relative or absolute probabilities known to the model.

    • Method Detail

      • hasModel

        boolean hasModel()
        Tests whether the model has been initialized, populated, or trained with data.
        Returns:
        "true" if at least one state transition is known to the model

      • allKnownStates

        Set<T> allKnownStates()
        The set of all "states" that the model is aware of. For example, if a MarkovChain<Character> is being used to generate random text, this returns the "alphabet". If a MarkovChain<String> is being used to simulate sentences, this returns the "vocabulary".
        Returns:
        a Set of known states

      • allPossibleNext

        Set<T> allPossibleNext(List<T> currentSequence)
        Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method provides the set of all the states that may occur next in the chain.
        Parameters:
        currentSequence - All states in this List must be known to the model, i.e., members of the set returned by allKnownStates().
        Returns:
        If the last state in the currentSequence is a "terminal state", that is, a state known to occur only at the end(s) of sequence(s), the return will be an empty set.

      • unweightedRandomNext

        T unweightedRandomNext(List<T> currentSequence)
        Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method chooses one state at random from the set of states that may occur next in the chain, without considering relative weights or probabilities.
        Parameters:
        currentSequence - All states in this List must be known to the model, i.e., members of the set returned by allKnownStates(). Furthermore, the last state in the sequence must not be a "terminal state", that is, one known to occur only at the end(s) of sequence(s).
        Returns:
        A state chosen by unweighted random draw.

      • weightedRandomNext

        T weightedRandomNext(List<T> currentSequence)
        Given a List<T> representing a sequence of states, this method chooses one state at random from the set of states that may occur next in the chain, based on a set of weights or an absolute or relative probability distribution of relative or absolute probabilities known to the model. I.e. if one state has twice the weight of another state in the transition model from the given state, it will be twice as likely to be drawn.
        Parameters:
        currentSequence - All states in this List must be known to the model, i.e., members of the set returned by allKnownStates(). Furthermore, the last state in the sequence must not be a "terminal state", that is, one known to occur only at the end(s) of sequence(s).
        Returns:
        A state chosen by weighted random draw.
